questions.text: What does the acronym DARP stand for in the context of FCS documentation?

options.B: Description, Assessment, Response, Plan

questions.explanation: DARP stands for Description, Assessment, Response, Plan. This format is commonly used for documenting enrollee interactions and contains all elements required for effective documentation (page 72).

questions.text: According to SMART goal format, what does the 'M' represent?

options.B: Measurable

questions.explanation: In SMART goals, M stands for Measurable. SMART goals are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-Bound (page 72).

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a required element in thorough Medicaid documentation?

options.A: Enrollee identification information on each page
options.B: Date, start time, end time, and duration of services

questions.explanation: A color-coded filing system is not mentioned as a required element. Required elements include enrollee identification, dates/times, legibility, and author identification (page 71).

questions.text: What should be included in the 'Description' section of a DARP progress note?

options.B: Objective and factual observations including date, times, and location

questions.explanation: The Description section should contain objective and factual observations, including date, exact start and end times (not rounded), location, and name of enrollee (page 72).

questions.text: What does TAP stand for in the FCS program?

options.B: Transition Assistance Program

questions.explanation: TAP stands for Transition Assistance Program, which provides time-limited funding for housing transitions (page 75).

questions.text: Which of the following is required for TAP enrollee eligibility?

options.B: Active FCS-eligible Medicaid and authorized for FCS supportive housing services
options.C: Must have a co-signer for housing

questions.explanation: TAP eligibility requires active FCS-eligible Medicaid, authorization by Wellpoint to receive FCS supportive housing services with active FCS-SH enrollment segments, experiencing a behavioral health treatment need, and making a housing transition (page 75).

questions.text: Which of the following moving expenses is NOT payable with TAP funding?

options.B: Moving supplies

questions.explanation: While moving vehicle rental, moving supplies, and appropriate reasonable expenses are covered, long-term storage fees are not listed as covered TAP expenses (pages 76-77).

questions.text: TAP funding can cover security deposits and first month's rent. What documentation must be included with a rental payment TAP request?

options.B: Rental ledger or official documentation reflecting the amount requested

questions.explanation: A rental ledger, or other official documentation, reflecting the amount requested must be included with the TAP request for rental payments (page 77).

questions.text: How long does an FCS provider have to spend TAP funding after receipt?

options.B: 60 days

questions.explanation: TAP funding should be spent within 90 days of receipt of the funds. Exceptions can be requested on a case-by-case basis (page 78).

questions.text: What should a provider do with excess TAP funds leftover after spending?

options.B: Donate them to charity
options.C: Use them towards other covered TAP items or return to Wellpoint
options.D: Transfer them to the enrollee's bank account

questions.explanation: Excess funds can be used towards other items that are covered under TAP or returned to Wellpoint by completing the TAP Overpayment Notification Form (page 78).

questions.text: Within how many business days does Wellpoint respond to a TAP request?

options.B: 5 business days

questions.explanation: Wellpoint responds to the FCS provider regarding the TAP request within five business days with an approval, denial, or rejection requesting more information (page 78).

questions.text: What does AHAH stand for?

options.B: Apple Health and Homes Program

questions.explanation: AHAH stands for Apple Health and Homes Program, which connects FCS enrollees with the Department of Commerce housing assistance (page 80).

questions.text: What does TBRA stand for in the AHAH program?

options.B: Tenant-Based Rental Assistance

questions.explanation: TBRA stands for Tenant-Based Rental Assistance. The AHAH program includes both TBRA and PBRA (Project-Based Rental Assistance) (page 80).

questions.text: What is the minimum age requirement for AHAH-RAP TBRA eligibility?

options.B: 17 years or older

questions.explanation: An individual must be 18 years or older to be eligible for AHAH-RAP TBRA, along with other requirements (page 80).

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor required for AHAH-RAP TBRA eligibility?

options.B: Frequent or lengthy institutional contacts

questions.explanation: The three risk factors for AHAH eligibility are chronic homelessness, frequent or lengthy institutional contacts, and frequent adult residential care stays. Frequent ER visits is not listed (page 80).

questions.text: What percentage of Fair Market Rent (FMR) does the AHAH-RAP TBRA voucher cover up to?

options.B: 115% of FMR

questions.explanation: The AHAH-RAP TBRA voucher will cover up to 130% of Fair Market Rent. The awardee is responsible for 30% of their income towards monthly rent (page 81).

questions.text: How long is the initial TBRA voucher valid before it expires?

options.B: 6 months with 90-day extensions

questions.explanation: All vouchers are awarded for six months to be utilized, with the possibility of extension in 90-day increments (page 83).

questions.text: For TBRA voucher awardee engagement, how many contact attempts must be made over what time period?

options.B: 4 attempts over 20 business days

questions.explanation: Providers and Wellpoint will make four attempts, over the course of 20 business days, with each attempt separated by a minimum of two business days. Two different contact methods must be used in total (page 83).

questions.text: What does the 'A' in SMART goals stand for?

options.B: Achievable

questions.explanation: In SMART goals, A stands for Achievable. Goals should be Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-Bound (page 72).

questions.text: What should be included to demonstrate that the enrollee is the primary author of their service/care plan?

options.B: Direct quotes from the enrollee and language they use and understand

questions.explanation: Evidence that the enrollee is the primary author includes direct quotes from the enrollee, cultural and linguistic considerations, and language that the enrollee uses and understands (page 72).

questions.text: Which of the following household items is payable with TAP funding under Household/Start-Up Goods?

options.B: Kitchen items for food preparation and consumption

questions.explanation: TAP covers essential household items including appliances and utensils, kitchen items for food preparation and consumption, bedding, furnishings, cribs, and bathroom supplies (page 77).

questions.text: When requesting TAP funding for utility arrears, what documentation must be included?

options.B: Copy of utility statement or official documentation reflecting the amount requested

questions.explanation: A copy of the utility statement, or other official documentation, reflecting the amount requested must be included with the TAP request for utility payments (page 78).

questions.text: Which assessments must be completed for an enrollee to be entered into the AHAH-RAP TBRA drawing?

options.A: Only the FCS Supportive Housing Assessment
options.B: Only the FCS Supported Employment Assessment
options.C: Both FCS Supportive Housing and Supported Employment Assessments

questions.explanation: FCS-SH providers must submit the FCS Supportive Housing Assessment with the AHAH-RAP section completed, and FCS-SE providers must submit the FCS Supported Employment Assessment. Enrollees need to be enrolled in both FCS-SH and FCS-SE services (page 81).

questions.text: Who acts as the Coordinating Entity between FCS providers and the Department of Commerce for AHAH?

options.A: The Department of Social and Health Services
options.B: Local housing authorities

questions.explanation: As the Coordinating Entity, Wellpoint acts as an intermediary between an FCS provider and the Department of Commerce Office of AHAH Permanent Supportive Housing (page 80).

questions.text: In the DARP format, what should the 'Response' section document?

options.B: The enrollee's reaction to interventions, including verbal and nonverbal cues

questions.explanation: The Response section documents the enrollee's reaction to interventions, including verbal feedback, changes in mood or behavior, and nonverbal cues (page 73).

questions.text: What type of document is a person-centered care plan described as?

options.A: A static document created at intake
options.B: An enrollee-driven living document that changes based on enrollee needs
options.D: A standardized form required by Medicaid

questions.explanation: Person-centered care plans are enrollee-driven living documents that should be changed based on enrollee needs, choices, strengths, and goals (page 72).

questions.text: What is the primary email address for TAP-related inquiries?

options.B: TransitionAssistanceFCS@Wellpoint.com

questions.explanation: The TAP contact email is TransitionAssistanceFCS@Wellpoint.com (page 79).

questions.text: How many regions are used for the AHAH-RAP TBRA drawing process?

options.B: 8 regions

questions.explanation: Wellpoint conducts a drawing for each of 10 regions in collaboration with state partners using a randomized regional drawing process (page 81).

questions.text: Which of the following identification-related expenses is covered by TAP?

options.B: Birth certificates and Social Security cards

questions.explanation: TAP covers identification documents/cards including birth certificates and Social Security cards (page 76).

questions.text: What should exact start and end times in documentation reflect?

options.A: Rounded to the nearest 15 minutes for billing purposes
options.B: Exact times, not rounded
options.D: General time ranges like morning or afternoon

questions.explanation: Documentation should include exact start and end times (not rounded) for services provided (page 72).

terms.definition: A commonly used format for documenting enrollee interactions that contains Description (objective observations), Assessment (evaluation of progress and barriers), Response (enrollee's reaction to interventions), and Plan (next steps and future interventions).
A goal-setting framework where all goals are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-Bound. Required format for treatment plan goals in FCS.

An enrollee-driven living document that changes based on enrollee needs, choices, strengths, and goals. Should include evidence that the enrollee is the primary author, such as direct quotes and language the enrollee uses and understands.

A supplementary FCS program providing time-limited funding for housing transitions, covering move-in costs, deposits, rental assistance, and other transition-related expenses for eligible FCS participants.

A program that connects FCS enrollees with the Department of Commerce housing assistance, including Tenant-Based and Project-Based Rental Assistance (TBRA and PBRA) and capital projects for permanent supportive housing.

A type of rental assistance through AHAH-RAP where the voucher covers up to 130% of Fair Market Rent, with the awardee responsible for 30% of their income towards monthly rent. Vouchers are valid for 6 months with possible 90-day extensions.
A type of rental assistance where the subsidy is tied to a specific housing unit or project rather than to the individual tenant. Part of the AHAH program's housing assistance options.
The standard rent amount used to determine AHAH-RAP TBRA voucher coverage. The voucher covers up to 130% of FMR, with the enrollee paying 30% of their income toward rent.
Apple Health and Homes Rental Assistance Program. The specific component of AHAH that provides rental assistance through a drawing process for eligible FCS enrollees.
The role Wellpoint plays in AHAH, acting as an intermediary between FCS providers and the Department of Commerce Office of AHAH Permanent Supportive Housing (PSH).
TAP funding should be spent within 90 days of receipt. Exceptions can be requested on a case-by-case basis. Excess funds can be used for other covered TAP items or returned to Wellpoint.
AHAH-RAP TBRA vouchers are awarded for six months with the possibility of extension in 90-day increments. The expiration date begins when the awardee and/or provider is notified of the award.

For TBRA voucher awardee engagement, providers must make four contact attempts over 20 business days, with each attempt separated by at least two business days, using two different contact methods in total.
A requirement for FCS service/care plans that must include clear documentation of why services and interventions are medically necessary for the enrollee.
Wellpoint responds to TAP requests within five business days with an approval, denial, or rejection requesting more information.
The process by which AHAH-RAP TBRA vouchers are awarded. Wellpoint conducts randomized drawings for each of 10 regions in collaboration with state partners.
Required elements of a treatment plan that identify both the positive attributes and skills the enrollee possesses and the obstacles they face in achieving their goals.

terms.term: Department of Commerce Office of AHAH-PSH
terms.definition: The state agency that serves as the payer of rental assistance in the AHAH program. Wellpoint acts as the Coordinating Entity between FCS providers and this office.
Essential items covered by TAP funding including appliances, utensils, kitchen items, bedding, furnishings, cribs, and bathroom supplies needed for housing transition.

One of three risk factors required for AHAH-RAP TBRA eligibility. An individual must be authorized by Wellpoint to receive FCS supportive housing services under this or another qualifying risk factor.

scenarios.title: TAP Funding Request for Move-In Costs
scenarios.description: Maria is an FCS-SH enrollee who has been approved for an apartment. She needs help with move-in costs including security deposit ($800), first month's rent ($950), rental application fee ($50), and moving truck rental ($150). She also needs basic household items including bedding ($200), kitchen items ($150), and bathroom supplies ($75).
scenarios.question: What is the correct process for requesting TAP funding for Maria's housing transition?

options.A: Submit separate TAP requests for each expense category to ensure faster processing
options.B: Submit one TAP request including all eligible expenses with rental ledger and wait for Wellpoint's response within 5 business days
options.C: Have Maria pay the costs first, then request reimbursement through TAP
options.D: Only request TAP funding for the security deposit and first month's rent, as other items aren't covered

scenarios.explanation: The provider should submit a complete TAP request using the online FCS TAP Request Form, including all eligible expenses. A rental ledger or official documentation must be included for rental payments. Wellpoint will respond within five business days. All the items mentioned (move-in costs, household goods) are covered TAP expenses. (Pages 76-78)

scenarios.title: DARP Documentation for Anxiety Management
scenarios.description: You're documenting a supportive housing visit with James, who has been working on managing anxiety in his new apartment. During the 45-minute visit from 2:00 PM to 2:45 PM on January 15, 2025, James reported feeling anxious about neighbor interactions. You observed he was fidgeting and had tense body language. You discussed coping strategies including deep breathing and listening to music. James said the breathing exercises helped him feel 'more in control.' You plan to check in next week about these strategies.
scenarios.question: Which documentation approach best follows the DARP format?

options.A: Combine all information in one paragraph noting the visit occurred and anxiety was discussed
options.B: Description: Visit details and observations; Assessment: Analysis of anxiety and progress; Response: James's reaction to interventions; Plan: Next steps for follow-up
options.C: Focus only on the anxiety symptoms observed without documenting the interventions provided
options.D: Document only the time and date, with a general note that James is 'doing fine'

scenarios.explanation: DARP format requires: Description (objective observations including exact date/times, location, enrollee name); Assessment (evaluation of progress, barriers, body language); Response/Action (interventions provided and enrollee's reaction); Plan (next steps and follow-up). Each section must be clearly documented with the provider's dated signature. (Pages 72-73)

scenarios.title: AHAH-RAP TBRA Drawing Process
scenarios.description: Sarah is eligible for AHAH-RAP TBRA. She is 25 years old, has active FCS-eligible Medicaid, is experiencing chronic homelessness, and is authorized for both FCS supportive housing and supported employment services. Her FCS-SH provider submitted the Supportive Housing Assessment with the AHAH-RAP section completed. Her name was drawn in the regional drawing and she received a welcome letter.
scenarios.question: What are the next required steps in the AHAH-RAP process?

options.A: Sarah can immediately start looking for housing with the voucher
options.B: The provider works with Sarah to complete the AHAH Awardee Profile, then a shopping letter is generated and sent so Sarah can secure housing
options.C: Sarah must wait for the Department of Commerce to approve her voucher before any further steps
options.D: The provider submits a new assessment to confirm Sarah's continued eligibility

scenarios.explanation: After the drawing and welcome letter, the process continues: provider and awardee complete the AHAH Awardee Profile, a shopping letter is generated based on this information, the voucher is reserved, and then the shopping letter is sent to Sarah and her provider to secure housing. Only after finding housing does the provider submit the voucher and landlord packet. (Page 81)

scenarios.title: TAP Funding Timeline Management
scenarios.description: Your agency received TAP funding of $2,500 for an enrollee on October 1st. The enrollee used $2,000 for move-in costs by November 15th. It's now December 20th (80 days since receipt), and the enrollee needs an additional $300 for utility connection fees. There's $500 remaining from the original TAP funding.
scenarios.question: How should you handle this situation?

options.A: Return the $500 to Wellpoint immediately as the 90-day period is almost expired
options.B: Use $300 from the remaining TAP funds for utility connection fees within the 90-day timeline, then handle any leftover funds appropriately
options.C: Request new TAP funding for the utility fees and return all $500 to Wellpoint
options.D: Save the $500 for future emergencies with this enrollee beyond the 90-day period

scenarios.explanation: TAP funding should be spent within 90 days of receipt. Since only 80 days have passed and utility connection fees are covered TAP expenses, the provider can use the remaining funds for this purpose. If funds are leftover after the need is met, they can be used for other covered TAP items or returned to Wellpoint using the TAP Overpayment Notification Form. (Pages 77-78)

scenarios.title: SMART Goal Development
scenarios.description: You're working with an enrollee to develop goals for their person-centered care plan. The enrollee says, 'I want to get better at managing my apartment and paying rent.' You need to help them develop this into a SMART goal.
scenarios.question: Which version best represents a SMART goal?

options.A: Enrollee will improve apartment management skills
options.B: Enrollee will pay rent on time every month for the next 6 months by using a budgeting app and setting payment reminders by March 1, 2025
options.C: Enrollee wants to be better at managing money and housing
options.D: Enrollee will work on improving rental payment consistency sometime in the future

scenarios.explanation: SMART goals must be Specific (pay rent on time), Measurable (every month for 6 months), Achievable (using tools like budgeting app), Relevant (directly addresses enrollee's stated need), and Time-Bound (by March 1, 2025). Option B meets all SMART criteria while using language the enrollee can understand. (Page 72)

scenarios.title: AHAH Voucher Expiration and Extension
scenarios.description: Robert received his AHAH-RAP TBRA voucher on February 10, 2025. He has been actively searching for housing with his provider's help but has faced challenges finding an available unit that meets his needs. It's now July 15, 2025.
scenarios.question: What is Robert's current voucher status and what options are available?

options.A: The voucher expired in May (after 3 months) and Robert must re-enter the drawing
options.B: The voucher is valid until August 10th (6 months) with no extension options
options.C: The original 6-month voucher expired, but Robert could have requested 90-day extensions if needed
options.D: The voucher never expires as long as Robert is actively searching for housing

scenarios.explanation: AHAH-RAP TBRA vouchers are awarded for six months (February 10 - August 10 in this case) with the possibility of extension in 90-day increments. Since it's July 15th, the voucher is still within the original 6-month period. If Robert needs more time after August 10th, he can request a 90-day extension. (Page 83)

scenarios.title: Awardee Engagement Due Diligence
scenarios.description: Lisa was drawn for an AHAH-RAP TBRA voucher on January 5th. Her provider sent a welcome email on January 5th (attempt 1), left a voicemail on January 9th (attempt 2), sent another email on January 12th (attempt 3), and made a final phone call on January 15th (attempt 4). It's now January 30th with no response from Lisa. She still has an active FCS-SH authorization.
scenarios.question: What should the provider do next according to AHAH engagement requirements?

options.A: Continue trying to contact Lisa indefinitely since she has an active authorization
options.B: Submit the Due Diligence Tracking Form to Wellpoint showing the 4 attempts over 20+ business days using 2 contact methods, and Wellpoint will move to the next awardee
options.C: Immediately request Wellpoint withdraw Lisa from AHAH-RAP
options.D: Wait another 30 days and then start the contact attempts over again

scenarios.explanation: The provider made 4 contact attempts over the required 20 business days using two different contact methods (email and phone). Since Lisa still has active FCS-SH authorization and there's been no response, the provider should internally track attempts and submit via the online Due Diligence Tracking Form. Wellpoint will then process and notify the provider they're moving to the next awardee. (Page 83)

scenarios.title: TAP Utility Documentation Requirements
scenarios.description: An enrollee needs help paying a past-due electric bill of $450 to prevent service disconnection. The provider wants to submit a TAP request to cover this utility arrear.
scenarios.question: What documentation must be included with the TAP request?

options.A: Only the enrollee's statement about the amount owed
options.B: A copy of the utility statement or official documentation reflecting the $450 amount requested
options.C: Proof of the enrollee's income to show they cannot pay
options.D: A letter from the utility company threatening disconnection

scenarios.explanation: For utility arrears, a copy of the utility statement, or other official documentation, reflecting the amount requested must be included with the TAP request. This ensures accurate payment of the actual amount owed. (Page 78)

scenarios.title: Person-Centered Care Plan Elements
scenarios.description: You're reviewing a care plan that was created for an enrollee. The plan includes provider-recommended goals written in clinical terminology, a list of diagnoses, scheduled appointment times, and provider signatures. The enrollee's signature appears at the bottom.
scenarios.question: What critical elements are missing to make this truly person-centered?

options.A: Nothing is missing; all required elements are present
options.B: Direct quotes from the enrollee, language they use and understand, their strengths and barriers, and evidence that the enrollee is the primary author
options.C: Medical necessity documentation and billing codes

scenarios.explanation: Person-centered care plans must include evidence that the enrollee is the primary author, such as direct quotes from the enrollee, cultural and linguistic considerations, and language the enrollee uses and understands. They should also include enrollee strengths and barriers, not just diagnoses. The plan should be enrollee-driven, not provider-recommended. (Page 72)

scenarios.title: AHAH-RAP Eligibility Verification
scenarios.description: Carlos is 17 years old, has active FCS-eligible Medicaid, is experiencing chronic homelessness, and is authorized for FCS supportive housing services. He is also enrolled in and assessed for FCS supported employment services. His provider wants to submit him for the AHAH-RAP TBRA drawing.
scenarios.question: Is Carlos eligible for AHAH-RAP TBRA? Why or why not?

options.A: Yes, he meets all eligibility requirements including both FCS-SH and FCS-SE enrollment
options.B: No, he is under 18 years old; TBRA eligibility requires being 18 or older
options.C: Yes, but only if he turns 18 before the next drawing
options.D: No, chronic homelessness alone is not sufficient for AHAH-RAP eligibility

scenarios.explanation: While Carlos meets most AHAH-RAP TBRA requirements (active FCS-eligible Medicaid, chronic homelessness risk factor, authorized for FCS-SH, enrolled in FCS-SE), he does not meet the age requirement. TBRA eligibility requires the individual to be 18 years or older. (Page 80)

scenarios.title: TAP Covered vs. Non-Covered Expenses
scenarios.description: An enrollee is transitioning into a new apartment and requests TAP funding assistance. They have a list of needed items: birth certificate ($25), rental application fee ($45), moving truck rental ($120), couch and coffee table ($400), basic kitchen utensils and dishes ($100), and a 55-inch flat screen TV ($600).
scenarios.question: Which items are NOT covered by TAP funding?

options.A: Birth certificate and rental application fee
options.B: Moving truck rental and kitchen items
options.C: The TV; all other items are covered TAP expenses

scenarios.explanation: TAP covers identification documents (birth certificate), rental application fees, moving vehicle rental, and household start-up goods including furnishings and kitchen items for food preparation and consumption. Entertainment systems like TVs are not listed as covered TAP expenses. (Pages 76-77)

scenarios.title: AHAH Voucher and Landlord Packet
scenarios.description: Jennifer has been awarded an AHAH-RAP TBRA voucher and found an apartment. Her provider needs to complete the voucher and landlord packet to submit to Wellpoint, who will then send it to the Department of Commerce for approval.
scenarios.question: Which documents are required in the combined Voucher and Landlord Packets?

options.A: Only the Intent to Rent Form and lease agreement
options.B: Provider Conflict of Interest Form, Intent to Rent Form, Income Verification, Housing Health and Safety Inspection, Lead-Based Paint Disclosure, Owner-Agent Verification, and Landlord Certification of Habitability
options.C: Just the provider's recommendation letter and Jennifer's housing history
options.D: Only landlord-related documents; the voucher packet is submitted separately

scenarios.explanation: The Voucher Packet includes Provider Conflict of Interest Form, Intent to Rent Form, Income Verification Worksheet, Verification of Short-Term Subsidy, Rent Allowance Request Form, AHAH-RAP Housing Health and Safety Inspection Form, and Lead-Based Paint Form & Pamphlet Disclosure. The Landlord Packet includes Landlord Intro Letter, Landlord Guide, Owner-Agent Verification Form, and Landlord Certification of Habitability. All are required. (Page 82)

talkingPoints.statement: In the DARP documentation format, exact start and end times should be rounded to the nearest 15 minutes for convenience.
talkingPoints.explanation: FALSE. Documentation must include exact start and end times that are NOT rounded. This is a requirement for accurate Medicaid documentation (page 72).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 6.1: Best Practices for Medicaid Documentation

talkingPoints.statement: Person-centered care plans are static documents created at intake and should remain unchanged throughout service delivery.
talkingPoints.explanation: FALSE. Person-centered care plans are enrollee-driven LIVING documents that should be changed based on enrollee needs, choices, strengths, and goals (page 72).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 6.1: Best Practices for Medicaid Documentation

talkingPoints.statement: SMART goals must be Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-Bound.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. All goals in treatment plans should be done in the SMART format, meaning they are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-Bound (page 72).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 6.1: Best Practices for Medicaid Documentation

talkingPoints.statement: TAP funding must be spent within 90 days of receipt, with exceptions available on a case-by-case basis.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. TAP funding should be spent within 90 days of receipt of the funds. Exceptions to this can be requested on a case-by-case basis (page 78).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 7.6: Spending TAP Funding

talkingPoints.statement: Wellpoint responds to TAP requests within 10 business days.
talkingPoints.explanation: FALSE. Wellpoint responds to TAP requests within FIVE business days with an approval, denial, or rejection requesting more information (page 78).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 7.5: Requesting TAP Funding

talkingPoints.statement: TAP can cover security deposits, first month's rent, and last month's rent.
talkingPoints.explanation: FALSE. TAP covers security deposits and first month's rent, but last month's rent is specifically noted as NOT HRSN Eligible on page 77.
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 7.3: Expenses Payable with TAP Funding

talkingPoints.statement: To be eligible for AHAH-RAP TBRA, an individual must be 18 years or older.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. One of the eligibility criteria for AHAH-RAP TBRA is being 18 years or older (page 80).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 8.1.1: TBRA Eligibility

talkingPoints.statement: The AHAH-RAP TBRA voucher covers up to 100% of Fair Market Rent.
talkingPoints.explanation: FALSE. The AHAH-RAP TBRA voucher covers up to 130% of Fair Market Rent, with the awardee responsible for 30% of their income towards monthly rent (page 81).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 8.2: Rental Assistance Subsidy

talkingPoints.statement: AHAH-RAP TBRA vouchers are valid for 6 months with possible 90-day extensions.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. All vouchers are awarded for six months to be utilized, with the possibility of extension in 90-day increments (page 83).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 8.6: TBRA Voucher Expiration

talkingPoints.statement: Wellpoint conducts the AHAH-RAP TBRA drawing for 10 regions across Washington State.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. Wellpoint conducts a drawing for each region (10 regions) in collaboration with state partners (page 81).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 8.3: TBRA Drawing

talkingPoints.statement: Evidence that the enrollee is the primary author of their service plan can include direct quotes from the enrollee and language they use and understand.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. Person-centered care plans should include evidence that the enrollee is the primary author, such as direct quotes from the enrollee, cultural and linguistic considerations, and language that the enrollee uses and understands (page 72).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 6.1: Best Practices for Medicaid Documentation

talkingPoints.statement: For AHAH-RAP TBRA eligibility, individuals must be authorized for both FCS supportive housing AND supported employment services.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. TBRA eligibility requires authorization by Wellpoint to receive both FCS supportive housing services (under qualifying risk factors) AND FCS supported employment services (page 80).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 8.1.1: TBRA Eligibility

talkingPoints.statement: The three risk factors for AHAH eligibility are chronic homelessness, frequent or lengthy institutional contacts, and frequent emergency room visits.
talkingPoints.explanation: FALSE. The three risk factors are chronic homelessness, frequent or lengthy institutional contacts, and frequent ADULT RESIDENTIAL CARE stays - not emergency room visits (page 80).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 8.1: Eligibility

talkingPoints.statement: Excess TAP funds can be used for other covered TAP items or must be returned to Wellpoint.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. Any excess funds leftover after spending can be used towards other items that are covered under TAP or returned to Wellpoint by completing the TAP Overpayment Notification Form (page 78).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 7.6: Spending TAP Funding

talkingPoints.statement: Providers must make 4 contact attempts over 20 business days for TBRA voucher awardee engagement, using at least two different contact methods.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. Providers and Wellpoint will make four attempts over 20 business days, with each attempt separated by a minimum of two business days. Two different contact methods must be used in total (page 83).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 8.5: TBRA Voucher Awardee Engagement

talkingPoints.statement: The DARP format includes Description, Assessment, Response, and Plan sections.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. DARP stands for Description, Assessment, Response, Plan and is commonly used for documenting enrollee interactions (page 72).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 6.1: Best Practices for Medicaid Documentation

talkingPoints.statement: TAP funding can cover birth certificates, Social Security cards, and other identification documents.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. TAP covers identification documents/cards including birth certificates and Social Security cards (page 76).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 7.3: Expenses Payable with TAP Funding

talkingPoints.statement: Wellpoint acts as the Coordinating Entity between FCS providers and the Department of Commerce for AHAH.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. As the Coordinating Entity, Wellpoint acts as an intermediary between an FCS provider and the Department of Commerce Office of AHAH Permanent Supportive Housing (page 80).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 8: Apple Health and Homes Program

talkingPoints.statement: Treatment plans must include dated signatures of both the enrollee and service provider.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. Required elements of a treatment plan include dated signatures of enrollee and service provider (page 72).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 6.1: Best Practices for Medicaid Documentation

talkingPoints.statement: A rental ledger or official documentation must be included with TAP requests for rental payments.
talkingPoints.explanation: TRUE. A rental ledger, or other official documentation, reflecting the amount requested must be included with the TAP request for rental-related expenses (page 77).
talkingPoints.sourceSection: Section 7.3: Expenses Payable with TAP Funding
